The list is far from complete. For a complete list of registered files inspect
Warning: This is not the same as get_bloginfo( 'url' ) (which will return the homepage url), but as get_bloginfo( 'wpurl' ).

do not need to be manually enqueued using wp_enqueue_script() if they are listed as a dependency of another script that is enqueued. WordPress will automatically include the registered script before it includes the enqueued script that lists the registered script’s handle as a dependency.
filter_function_name should be unique function name. It cannot match any other function name already declared.
$_term is now a WP_Term object.
$args can be passed to set flags on the setting, similar to register_meta().
$args can now also be an object.
$classes is a space-separated string of class names instead of an array.
$default is now returned early when the setting post value is invalid.
$identifier should be a unique identifier for the test that should run. Plugins and themes are encouraged to prefix test identifiers with their slug to avoid any collisions between tests.

$is_single, $is_page, $is_archive, $is_preview, $is_date, $is_year, $is_month, $is_time, $is_author, $is_category, $is_tag, $is_tax, $is_search, $is_feed, $is_comment_feed, $is_trackback, $is_home, $is_404, $is_comments_popup, $is_admin, $is_attachment, $is_singular, $is_robots, $is_posts_page, $is_paged
$pages added as arguments.
$post argument was added.
$post can be a post ID or WP_Post object.
$post_id can be a WP_Post object.
$prepared_comment can now be a WP_Error to shortcircuit insertion.
$r and $pages added as arguments.
$sanitize_callback was deprecated. The callback from register_setting() is now used instead.
$taxonomy is optional if $field is 'term_taxonomy_id'. Converted to return a WP_Term object if $output is OBJECT.
$translations was added as a possible argument to $hook_extra.
$uri can be an array of URIs.
$username now accepts an email address.
'admin_email' – E-mail address of blog administrator.
'blog_charset' – Character encoding for your blog; set in Reading Options.
'blogdescription' – Tagline for your blog; set in General Options.
'blogname' – Weblog title; set in General Options.
'date_format' – Default date format; set in General Options.
'default_category' – Default post category; set in Writing Options.
'home' – The blog’s home web address; set in General Options.
'posts_per_page' – Maximum number of posts to show on a page; set in Reading Options.
'posts_per_rss' – Maximum number of most recent posts to show in the syndication feed; set in Reading Options.
'siteurl' – WordPress web address; set in General Options.
'start_of_week' – Day of week calendar should start on; set in General Options.
'template' – The current theme’s name; set in Presentation.
'upload_path' – Default upload location; set in Miscellaneous Options.
'users_can_register' – Whether users can register; set in General Options.
WP_DEBUG must be true in addition to the filter evaluating to true.
WP_DEBUG_DISPLAY and WP_DEBUG_LOG perform no function unless WP_DEBUG is true.
WP_DEBUG_LOG can be a file path.
X-Pingback header is added conditionally after posts have been queried in handle_404().

add_new – Default is ‘Add New’ for both hierarchical and non-hierarchical types. When internationalizing this string, please use a gettext context matching your post type. Example: _x( 'Add New', 'product', 'textdomain' );.
add_new_item – Label for adding a new singular item. Default is ‘Add New Post’ / ‘Add New Page’.
all_items – Label to signify all items in a submenu link. Default is ‘All Posts’ / ‘All Pages’.
archives – Label for archives in nav menus. Default is ‘Post Archives’ / ‘Page Archives’.
attributes – Label for the attributes meta box. Default is ‘Post Attributes’ / ‘Page Attributes’.
auth: Authentication handler or array of user/password details to use for Basic authentication (Requests_Auth|array|boolean, default: false)
blocking: Should we block processing on this request? (boolean, default: true)

complete: A callback for when a request is complete. Takes two parameters, a Requests_Response/Requests_Exception reference, and the ID from the request array (Note: this can also be overridden on a per-request basis, although that’s a little silly) (callback)
connect_timeout: How long should we wait while trying to connect? (float, seconds with a millisecond precision, default: 10, example: 0.01)
cookies: Associative array of cookie name to value, or cookie jar. (array|Requests_Cookie_Jar)
data: Associative array of data fields or a string. Same as the $data parameter to Requests::request (array|string, default: array())
data_format: How should we send the $data parameter? (string, one of ‘query’ or ‘body’, default: ‘query’ for HEAD/GET/DELETE, ‘body’ for POST/PUT/OPTIONS/PATCH)
edit_item – Label for editing a singular item. Default is ‘Edit Post’ / ‘Edit Page’.
editor-style: Use add_editor_style() instead.
featured_image – Label for the Featured Image meta box title. Default is ‘Featured Image’.
filename: File to stream the body to instead. (string|boolean, default: false)
filter_items_list – Label for the table views hidden heading. Default is ‘Filter posts list’ / ‘Filter pages list’.
follow_redirects: Should we follow 3xx redirects? (boolean, default: true)
form removed as allowable HTML tag.
get_option( 'page_for_posts' ): returns the ID of the static page assigned to the blog posts index (posts page)
get_option( 'page_on_front' ): returns the ID of the static page assigned to the front page
get_option( 'show_on_front' ): returns either 'posts' or 'page'
headers: Associative array of header fields. Same as the $headers parameter to Requests::request (array, default: array())
hooks: Hooks handler. (Requests_Hooker, default: new Requests_Hooks())
idn: Enable IDN parsing (boolean, default: true)
insert_into_item – Label for the media frame button. Default is ‘Insert into post’ / ‘Insert into page’.
is_front_page() will return false
is_front_page() will return true
is_home() will return false
is_home() will return true
is_main_query() may be used with both front-end queries (theme templates, plugins, etc.), as well as admin queries. It will return true if the current query is the main query, and false if not.
item_published – Label used when an item is published. Default is ‘Post published.’ / ‘Page published.’
item_published_privately – Label used when an item is published with private visibility. Default is ‘Post published privately.’ / ‘Page published privately.’
item_reverted_to_draft – Label used when an item is switched to a draft. Default is ‘Post reverted to draft.’ / ‘Page reverted to draft.’
item_scheduled – Label used when an item is scheduled for publishing. Default is ‘Post scheduled.’ / ‘Page scheduled.’
item_updated – Label used when an item is updated. Default is ‘Post updated.’ / ‘Page updated.’
items_list – Label for the table hidden heading. Default is ‘Posts list’ / ‘Pages list’.
items_list_navigation – Label for the table pagination hidden heading. Default is ‘Posts list navigation’ / ‘Pages list navigation’.
max_bytes: Limit for the response body size. (integer|boolean, default: false)
menu_name – Label for the menu name. Default is the same as name.
menus: Use register_nav_menu() or register_nav_menus() instead.
meta_query also contains one or more arrays with the following keys:
name – General name for the post type, usually plural. The same and overridden by $post_type_object->label. Default is ‘Posts’ / ‘Pages’.
new_item – Label for the new item page title. Default is ‘New Post’ / ‘New Page’.
not_found – Label used when no items are found. Default is ‘No posts found’ / ‘No pages found’.
not_found_in_trash – Label used when no items are in the trash. Default is ‘No posts found in Trash’ / ‘No pages found in Trash’.
parent_item_colon – Label used to prefix parents of hierarchical items. Not used on non-hierarchical post types. Default is ‘Parent Page:’.
proxy: Proxy details to use for proxy by-passing and authentication (Requests_Proxy|array|string|boolean, default: false)

query_posts() will change your main query and is not recommended. Only use if absolutely necessary. Creating a new instance of WP_Query or get_posts() is preferred for secondary loops. If you would like to modify the main query, use the pre_get_posts action.
redirects: How many times should we redirect before erroring? (integer, default: 10)
remove_featured_image – Label for removing the featured image. Default is ‘Remove featured image’.
search_items – Label for searching plural items. Default is ‘Search Posts’ / ‘Search Pages’.
set_featured_image – Label for setting the featured image. Default is ‘Set featured image’.
sidebars: Use register_sidebar() or register_sidebars() instead.
single-{post_type}-{post_name}.php was added to the top of the template hierarchy.
singular_name – Name for one object of this post type. Default is ‘Post’ / ‘Page’.

timeout: How long should we wait for a response? Note: for cURL, a minimum of 1 second applies, as DNS resolution operates at second-resolution only. (float, seconds with a millisecond precision, default: 10, example: 0.01)
transport: Custom transport. Either a class name, or a transport object. Defaults to the first working transport from getTransport() (string|Requests_Transport, default: getTransport())
type: HTTP request type (use Requests constants). Same as the $type parameter to Requests::request (string, default: Requests::GET)
uploaded_to_this_item – Label for the media frame filter. Default is ‘Uploaded to this post’ / ‘Uploaded to this page’.
url: Request URL Same as the $url parameter to Requests::request (string, required)
use_featured_image – Label in the media frame for using a featured image. Default is ‘Use as featured image’.
useragent: Useragent to send to the server (string, default: php-requests/$version)

verify: Should we verify SSL certificates? Allows passing in a custom certificate file as a string. (Using true uses the system-wide root certificate store instead, but this may have different behaviour across transports.) (string|boolean, default: library/Requests/Transport/cacert.pem)
verifyname: Should we verify the common name in the SSL certificate? (boolean: default, true)
view_item – Label for viewing a singular item. Default is ‘View Post’ / ‘View Page’.
view_items – Label for viewing post type archives. Default is ‘View Posts’ / ‘View Pages’.
{Post Type Template}.php was added to the top of the template hierarchy.
By using the ‘meta_value’ parameter the value 99 will be considered greater than 100 as the data are stored as ‘strings’, not ‘numbers’. For number comparison use ‘meta_value_num’.

Using $headers To Set “From:”, “Cc:” and “Bcc:” Parameters
Valid Address Formats
Display posts from the current page and set the ‘paged’ parameter to 1 when the query variable is not set (first page).
‘orderby’ with ‘meta_value’ and custom post type
‘orderby’ with multiple ‘meta_key’s
'all' – Return all fields (default).
'id=>parent' – Return an array of stdClass objects with ID and post_parent properties.
'ids' – Return an array of post IDs.
after (string/array) – Date to retrieve posts after. Accepts strtotime()-compatible string, or array of ‘year’, ‘month’, ‘day’ values:
author (int) – use author id.
author__in (array) – use author id (available since version 3.7).
author__not_in (array) – use author id (available since version 3.7).
author_name (string) – use ‘user_nicename‘ – NOT name.
before (string/array) – Date to retrieve posts before. Accepts strtotime()-compatible string, or array of ‘year’, ‘month’, ‘day’ values:
cache_results (boolean) – Post information cache.
cat (int) – use category id.
category__and (array) – use category id.
category__in (array) – use category id.
category__not_in (array) – use category id.
category_name (string) – use category slug.
column (string) – Posts column to query against. Default: ‘post_date’.
comment_count (Array) – If comment_count is an array, it should have two arguments:
comment_count (int) – The amount of comments your CPT has to have ( Search operator will do a ‘=’ operation )

compare (string) – Operator to test. Possible values are ‘=’, ‘!=’, ‘>’, ‘>=’, ‘<‘, ‘<=’, ‘LIKE’, ‘NOT LIKE’, ‘IN’, ‘NOT IN’, ‘BETWEEN’, ‘NOT BETWEEN’, ‘EXISTS’ and ‘NOT EXISTS’. Default value is ‘=’.
compare (string) – See WP_Date_Query::get_compare().
date_query (array) – Date parameters (available since version 3.7).
day (int) – Day of the month (from 1 to 31).
day (string) The day of the month. Accepts numbers 1-31. Default: 1.
day (string) The day of the month. Accepts numbers 1-31. Default: last day of month.
field (string) – Select taxonomy term by. Possible values are ‘term_id’, ‘name’, ‘slug’ or ‘term_taxonomy_id’. Default value is ‘term_id’.
fields (string) – Which fields to return. There are three options:
has_password (bool) – true for posts with passwords ; false for posts without passwords ; null for all posts with and without passwords (available since version 3.9).
hour (int) – Hour (from 0 to 23).

ignore_sticky_posts (boolean) – ignore post stickiness (available since version 3.1, replaced caller_get_posts parameter). false (default): move sticky posts to the start of the set. true: do not move sticky posts to the start of the set.
include_children (boolean) – Whether or not to include children for hierarchical taxonomies. Defaults to true.
inclusive (boolean) – For after/before, whether exact value should be matched or not’.
key (string) – Custom field key.
m (int) – YearMonth (For e.g.: 201307).

meta_compare (string) – Operator to test the ‘meta_value‘. Possible values are ‘=’, ‘!=’, ‘>’, ‘>=’, ‘<‘, ‘<=’, ‘LIKE’, ‘NOT LIKE’, ‘IN’, ‘NOT IN’, ‘BETWEEN’, ‘NOT BETWEEN’, ‘NOT EXISTS’, ‘REGEXP’, ‘NOT REGEXP’ or ‘RLIKE’. Default value is ‘=’.
meta_key (string) – Custom field key.
meta_query (array) – Custom field parameters (available since version 3.1).
meta_value (string) – Custom field value.
meta_value_num (number) – Custom field value.
minute (int) – Minute (from 0 to 59).
minute (int) – Minute (from 0 to 60).
month (int) – Month number (from 1 to 12).
month (string) The month of the year. Accepts numbers 1-12. Default: 1.
month (string) The month of the year. Accepts numbers 1-12. Default: 12.
monthnum (int) – Month number (from 1 to 12).
name (string) – use post slug.
nopaging (boolean) – show all posts or use pagination. Default value is ‘false’, use paging.

offset (int) – number of post to displace or pass over. Warning: Setting the offset parameter overrides/ignores the paged parameter and breaks pagination. The 'offset' parameter is ignored when 'posts_per_page'=>-1 (show all posts) is used.
operator (string) – Operator to test. Possible values are ‘IN’, ‘NOT IN’, ‘AND’, ‘EXISTS’ and ‘NOT EXISTS’. Default value is ‘IN’.
order (string | array) – Designates the ascending or descending order of the ‘orderby‘ parameter. Defaults to ‘DESC’. An array can be used for multiple order/orderby sets.
orderby (string | array) – Sort retrieved posts by parameter. Defaults to ‘date (post_date)’. One or more options can be passed.
p (int) – use post id.
page (int) – number of page for a static front page. Show the posts that would normally show up just on page X of a Static Front Page.
page_id (int) – use page id.
paged (int) – number of page. Show the posts that would normally show up just on page X when using the “Older Entries” link.
pagename (string) – use page slug.
perm (string) – User permission.

post__in (array) – use post ids. Specify posts to retrieve. ATTENTION If you use sticky posts, they will be included (prepended!) in the posts you retrieve whether you want it or not. To suppress this behaviour use ignore_sticky_posts.
post__not_in (array) – use post ids. Specify post NOT to retrieve.
post_mime_type (string/array) – Allowed mime types.
post_name__in (array) – use post slugs. Specify posts to retrieve. (Will be available in version 4.4)
post_parent (int) – use page id to return only child pages. Set to 0 to return only top-level entries.
post_parent__in (array) – use post ids. Specify posts whose parent is in an array. (available since version 3.6)
post_parent__not_in (array) – use post ids. Specify posts whose parent is not in an array. (available since version 3.6)
post_password (string) – show posts with a particular password (available since version 3.9)

post_status (string / array) – use post status. Retrieves posts by post status. Default value is ‘publish‘, but if the user is logged in, ‘private‘ is added. Public custom post statuses are also included by default. And if the query is run in an admin context (administration area or AJAX call), protected statuses are added too. By default protected statuses are ‘future‘, ‘draft‘ and ‘pending‘.
post_type (string / array) – use post types. Retrieves posts by post types, default value is ‘post‘. If ‘tax_query‘ is set for a query, the default value becomes ‘any‘;
posts_per_archive_page (int) – number of posts to show per page – on archive pages only. Over-rides posts_per_page and showposts on pages where is_archive() or is_search() would be true.

posts_per_page (int) – number of post to show per page (available since version 2.1, replaced showposts parameter). Use 'posts_per_page'=>-1 to show all posts (the 'offset' parameter is ignored with a -1 value). Set the ‘paged’ parameter if pagination is off after using this parameter. Note: if the query is in a feed, wordpress overwrites this parameter with the stored ‘posts_per_rss’ option. To reimpose the limit, try using the ‘post_limits’ filter, or filter ‘pre_option_posts_per_rss’ and return -1
relation (string) – OR or AND, how the sub-arrays should be compared. Default: AND.
relation (string) – The logical relationship between each inner meta_query array when there is more than one. Possible values are ‘AND’, ‘OR’. Do not use with a single inner meta_query array.
relation (string) – The logical relationship between each inner taxonomy array when there is more than one. Possible values are ‘AND’, ‘OR’. Do not use with a single inner taxonomy array.
s (string) – Search keyword.
second (int) – Second (0 to 59).
second (int) – Second (0 to 60).
tag (string) – use tag slug.
tag__and (array) – use tag ids.
tag__in (array) – use tag ids.
tag__not_in (array) – use tag ids.
tag_id (int) – use tag id.
tag_slug__and (array) – use tag slugs.
tag_slug__in (array) – use tag slugs.
tax_query (array) – use taxonomy parameters (available since version 3.1).
taxonomy (string) – Taxonomy.
terms (int/string/array) – Taxonomy term(s).
type (string) – Custom field type. Possible values are ‘NUMERIC’, ‘BINARY’, ‘CHAR’, ‘DATE’, ‘DATETIME’, ‘DECIMAL’, ‘SIGNED’, ‘TIME’, ‘UNSIGNED’. Default value is ‘CHAR’.
update_post_meta_cache (boolean) – Post meta information cache.
update_post_term_cache (boolean) – Post term information cache.

value (string|array) – Custom field value. It can be an array only when compare is 'IN', 'NOT IN', 'BETWEEN', or 'NOT BETWEEN'. You don’t have to specify a value when using the 'EXISTS' or 'NOT EXISTS' comparisons in WordPress 3.9 and up.
w (int) – Week of the year (from 0 to 53). Uses MySQL WEEK command. The mode is dependent on the “start_of_week” option.
week (int) – Week of the year (from 0 to 53).
year (int) – 4 digit year (e.g. 2011).
year (string) Accepts any four-digit year. Default is empty.
{tax} (string) – use taxonomy slug. (Deprecated since version 3.1 in favor of ‘tax_query‘).

NOTE:Ticket #28099: Passing an empty array to post__in will return has_posts() as true (and all posts will be returned). Logic should be used before hand to determine if WP_Query should be used in the event that the array being passed to post__in is empty.

Note: If you use the_post() with your query, you need to run wp_reset_postdata() afterwards to have template tags use the main query’s current post again.
Note: you cannot combine post__in and post__not_in in the same query.
Note:Ticket #18408 For querying posts in the admin, consider using get_posts() as wp_reset_postdata() might not behave as expected.

<tt>register_setting</tt>()
?page=my-super-plugin/admin-options.php
?page=my_super_plugin_page
A

A "first-order" clause is one that contains any of the first-order clause keys (‘terms’, ‘taxonomy’, ‘include_children’, ‘field’, ‘operator’). An empty clause also counts as a first-order clause, for backward compatibility. Any clause that doesn’t meet this is determined, by process of elimination, to be a higher-order query.
A "hard" flush updates .htaccess (Apache) or web.config (IIS).
A 'Y/m/d'-formatted date for 'post' post type, the 'singular_name' post type label otherwise.
A 'meta_input' array can now be passed to $postarr to add post meta data.
A WP_Error instance

A WP_Error instance can be returned if an error occurs, and this should match the format used by API methods internally (that is, the status data should be used). A callback can return true to indicate that the authentication method was used, and it succeeded.
A WP_Error object possibly containing 'blogname' or 'blog_title' errors.
A WP_Error object with possible errors relevant to new site creation variables.
A WP_Error object with possible errors relevant to the sign-up user.
A WP_User object is returned if the credentials authenticate a user. WP_Error or null otherwise.
A UI container for controls, managed by the WP_Customize_Manager class.
A UI container for sections, managed by the WP_Customize_Manager.
A UI container for theme controls, which are displayed within sections.
A URL to include a link to. Only works in combination with $link_text. Default empty string.

A URL will only be returned if the WP_DIRECT_UPDATE_PHP_URL environment variable is specified or by using the ‘wp_direct_php_update_url’ filter. This allows hosts to send users directly to the page where they can update PHP to a newer version.
A callable to perform a direct test, or a string AJAX action to be called to perform an async test.
A callback function that sanitizes the option's value.
A class for displaying various tree-like structures.
A client for api.wordpress.org/events.
A comma-separated list of IDs of attachments to display. Default empty.
A comma-separated list of IDs of attachments to exclude. Default empty.
A comma-separated list of IDs of attachments to include. Default empty.
A comma-separated list of author IDs.
A comma-separated list or array of post statuses to include. Default 'publish'.
A concise list of commonly-used options is below, but a more complete one can be found at the Option Reference.
A conditional check to test whether the page is a date-based archive page displaying posts for the current day.
A constant WP_DISABLE_FATAL_ERROR_HANDLER can be set in wp-config.php to disable it, or alternatively the ‘wp_fatal_error_handler_enabled’ filter can be used to modify the return value.
A container div will always be printed in the Customizer preview.
A description of the data attached to this meta key.
A description of the data attached to this setting.
A descriptive name for the post status marked for translation. Defaults to value of $post_status.

A drop-in ‘fatal-error-handler.php’ can be used to override the instance of this class and use a custom implementation for the fatal error handler that WordPress registers. The custom class should extend this class and can override its methods individually as necessary. The file must return the instance of the class that should be registered.

A drop-in ‘php-error.php’ can be used as a custom template. This drop-in should control the HTTP status code and print the HTML markup indicating that a PHP error occurred. Note that this drop-in may potentially be executed very early in the WordPress bootstrap process, so any core functions used that are not part of wp-includes/load.php should be checked for before being called.
A false return value might also mean that the post type does not exist.
A false return value might also mean that the taxonomy does not exist.
A first-order meta query clause is one that has either a ‘key’ or a ‘value’ array key.
A friendly label for your test to identify it by.
A function or method to call when sanitizing $meta_key data.
A gettext Plural-Forms parser.
A group of regex replaces used to identify text formatted with newlines and replace double line-breaks with HTML paragraph tags. The remaining line-breaks after conversion become <
A helper function that is used primarily to check whether a blog has exceeded its allowed upload space.
A helper function to calculate the image sources to include in a ‘srcset’ attribute.

A key is considered ‘expired’ if it exactly matches the value of the user_activation_key field, rather than being matched after going through the hashing process. This field is now hashed; old values are no longer accepted but have a different WP_Error code so good user feedback can be provided.
A label for the link to include. Only works in combination with $link_url. Default empty string.
A list of all themes installed in sent to WP. Checks against the WordPress server at api.wordpress.org. Will only check if WordPress isn’t installing.

A loopback is when WordPress queries itself, for example to start a new WP_Cron instance, or when editing a plugin or theme. This has shown itself to be a recurring issue as code can very easily break this interaction.
A lot like wp_count_comments(), in that they both return comment stats (albeit with different types). The wp_count_comments() actually caches, but this function does not.
A mime icon for files, thumbnail or intermediate size for images.
A network ID or array of network IDs. Set to null to retrieve sites from all networks. Defaults to current network ID.
A new query var with the same name as the endpoint will also be created.
A new user registration notification is also sent to admin email.
A non-existent term is inserted in the following sequence:
A non-filtered, non-cached version of wp_upload_dir() that doesn’t check the path.
A non-null string must be returned for the filter to be evaluated.
A nonce has a lifespan of two ticks. Nonces in their second tick may be updated, e.g. by autosave.
A number of characters are removed from the URL. If the URL is for displaying (the default behaviour) ampersands are also replaced. The ‘clean_url’ filter is applied to the returned cleaned URL.
A number of characters are removed from the URL. If the URL is for displaying (the default behaviour) ampersands are also replaced. The ‘clean_url’ filter is applied to the returned cleaned URL.
A number to add.
A numeric string is considered to be an existing user ID and is simply returned as such.

A permalink structure (permastruct) is an abstract definition of a set of rewrite rules; it is an easy way of expressing a set of regular expressions that rewrite to a set of query strings. The new permastruct is added to the WP_Rewrite::$extra_permastructs array.
A plugin (or theme) can register as a content filter with the code:

A plugin can modify data by binding a callback to a filter hook. When the filter is later applied, each bound callback is run in order of priority, and given the opportunity to modify a value by returning a new value.

A plugin may use the ‘image_downsize’ filter to hook into and offer image resizing services for images. The hook must return an array with the same elements that are returned in the function. The first element being the URL to the new image that was resized.

A plugin or theme can use this function multiple times as long as it will help to better present the suggested policy content. For example modular plugins such as WooCommerse or Jetpack can add or remove suggested content depending on the modules/extensions that are enabled. For more information see the Plugin Handbook: https://developer.wordpress.org/plugins/privacy/suggesting-text-for-the-site-privacy-policy/.
A plugin that is already activated will not attempt to be activated again.
A post status (string) or array of post statuses.
A post type slug (string) or array of post type slugs. Default 'any' if using 'tax_query'.
A quick procedural method to removing all of the filters that KSES uses for content in WordPress Loop.
A relationship means that the term is grouped in or belongs to the taxonomy. A term has no meaning until it is given context by defining which taxonomy it exists under.
A return value of 1 means the file path contains directory traversal.
A return value of 2 means the file path contains a Windows drive path.
A return value of 3 means the file is not in the allowed files list.
A return value was added.
A safe way to add/enqueue a stylesheet file to the WordPress generated page.
A search term.
A second number to add.

A secondary query loop using $sec_query = new WP_Query() and $sec_query->the_post() affects the global $post variable. The global $post variable is used by template tags by default. wp_reset_postdata() restores the global $post variable to the current post in the main query (contained in the global $wp_query variable as opposed to the $sec_query variable), so that the template tags refer to the main query loop by default again.
A session token is a long, random string. It is used in a cookie to link that cookie to an expiration time and to ensure the cookie becomes invalidated when the user logs out.
A setting that is used to filter a value, but will not save the results.
A short descriptive summary of what the post type is.
A short descriptive summary of what the taxonomy is for.
A simple function for creating or modifying a post status based on the parameters given. The function will accept an array (second optional parameter), along with a string for the post status name.

A simple function for creating or modifying a taxonomy object based on the parameters given. If modifying an existing taxonomy object, note that the $object_type value from the original registration will be overwritten.
A simple wrapper to display the "s" parameter in a GET URI. This function should only be used when the_search_query() cannot.
A simpler way of inserting a user into the database.
A site ID to only return that site.
A site is considered initialized when its database tables are present.
A string to appear before the page number.
A string to append after the page number.
A string to append to each link.
A subtype; e.g. if the object type is "post", the post type. If left empty, the meta key will be registered on the entire object type. Default empty.
A theme with errors exists. A theme with the error of ‘theme_not_found’, meaning that the theme’s directory was not found, does not exist.
A true return value does not automatically mean that the user received the email successfully. It just only means that the method used was able to process the request without any errors.

A variety of taxonomy drop-down display elements can be modified just prior to display via this filter. Filterable arguments include ‘show_option_none’, ‘show_option_all’, and various forms of the term name.
A wrapper for PHP’s parse_url() function that handles consistency in the return values across PHP versions.
A wrapper for get_sql_for_clause(), included here for backward compatibility while retaining the naming convention across Query classes.

ABSPATH is always checked in addition to whatever $context is (which may be the wp-content directory, for example). The underlying assumption is that if you are using version control anywhere, then you should be making decisions for how things get updated.
ADMIN_URL### The link to click on to confirm the email change.
AE
AJAX Cat
API for easily embedding rich media such as videos and images into content.
ARIA label for the search form. Useful to distinguish multiple search forms on the same page and improve accessibility.
Aa
Abort if the Destination directory exists.
Aborts calls to site meta if it is not supported.
Aborts calls to term meta if it is not supported.
Above, the first default value is for non-hierarchical post types (like posts) and the second one is for hierarchical post types (like pages).
Absolute path to an SSL certificate .crt file. Default ABSPATH . WPINC . '/certificates/ca-bundle.crt'.
Abstract class for managing user session tokens.
Accepted ‘filter’ keys are ‘parent_id’, ‘mime_type’, ‘offset’, and ‘number’.
Accepted ‘filter’ keys are ‘status’, ‘post_id’, ‘offset’, and ‘number’.
Accepted keys of the label array in the post type object:
Accepts ‘blank’, and otherwise uses sanitize_hex_color_no_hash(). Returns default text color if hex color is empty.
Accepts an associative array $l10n and creates a JavaScript object:
Accepts an optional $reassign parameter, if you want to reassign the user’s blog posts to another user upon removal.

Accepts either a string or an array and then parses that against a set of default arguments for the new sidebar. WordPress will automatically generate a sidebar ID and name based on the current number of registered sidebars if those arguments are not included.
Accepts either a valid email address or empty string as a valid comment author email address. Setting the comment author email to an empty string is allowed when a comment is being updated.
Accepts matches array from preg_replace_callback in wpautop() or a string.
Accepts one argument: $stylesheet of the theme. It also accepts an additional function signature of two arguments: $template then $stylesheet. This is for backward compatibility.
Access the WordPress Recovery Mode instance.
Access the pagination args.
Accesses the Name header directly from the class for maximum speed. Would choke on HTML but we don’t care enough to slow it down with strip_tags().
Action hook to execute when the event is run.

Actions are the hooks that the WordPress core launches at specific points during execution, or when specific events occur. Plugins can specify that one or more of its PHP functions are executed at these points, using the Action API.
Actions column.
Actions column. Overridden by children.
Activate a signup.
Activate multiple plugins.
Active callback.
Acts on text which is about to be edited.
Adapt the bias

Added 'nicename', 'nicename__in', 'nicename__not_in', 'login', 'login__in', and 'login__not_in' parameters.

Added 'paged', 'role__in', and 'role__not_in' parameters. The 'role' parameter was updated to permit an array or comma-separated list of values. The 'number' parameter was updated to support querying for all users with using -1.
Added 'post_name__in' support for $orderby. Introduced the $lazy_load_term_meta argument.
Added 'slug__in' support for 'orderby'.
Added 'urn' to the protocols array.

Alias of update_post_cache().
Alias of wp_unregister_widget_control().
Aliases wp_insert_category() with minimal args.
All Menu Items
All built-in XML-RPC methods use the action xmlrpc_call, with a parameter equal to the method’s name, e.g., wp.getUsersBlogs, wp.newPost, etc.
All categories.
All chosen/entered details are saved, excluding the password.

All core features are directly associated with a functional area of the edit screen, such as the editor or a meta box. Features include: ‘title’, ‘editor’, ‘comments’, ‘revisions’, ‘trackbacks’, ‘author’, ‘excerpt’, ‘page-attributes’, ‘thumbnail’, ‘custom-fields’, and ‘post-formats’.
All email addresses supplied to
All hooks have default priority. The wp_filter_kses() function is added to the ‘pre_comment_content’ and ‘title_save_pre’ hooks.

All of the capabilities of the roles of the user are merged with the user’s individual capabilities. This means that the user can be denied specific capabilities that their role might have, but the user is specifically denied.
All of the categories for the current post in the feed loop, will be retrieved and have feed markup added, so that they can easily be added to the RSS2, Atom, or RSS1 and RSS0.91 RDF feeds.
All of the headers in $res[‘headers’] are with the name as the key and the
All placeholders MUST be left unquoted in the query string. A corresponding argument MUST be passed for each placeholder.
All settings IDs tied to the partial. If undefined, $id will be used.
All settings tied to the control. If undefined, $id will be used.
All settings tied to the control. If undefined, defaults to $setting. IDs in the array correspond to the ID of a registered WP_Customize_Setting.
All strings are expected to be plain text except $description that can contain inline HTML tags (see below).
Allow hijacking the request before dispatching by returning a non-empty. The returned value will be used to serve the request instead.
Allow hijacking the setting value and overriding the built-in behavior by returning a non-null value. The returned value will be presented as the setting value instead.
Allow non-statically created partials to be constructed with custom WP_Customize_Partial subclass.
Allow non-statically created settings to be constructed with custom WP_Customize_Setting subclass.
Allow non-statically created settings to be constructed with custom WP_Customize_Setting subclass.
Allow plugins to override dispatching the request.
Allow returning users to sign up for another site
Allow sending the request manually – by returning true, the API result will not be sent to the client.
Allow subdirectory installation.
Allow subdomain installation
Allows $name to be an array that accepts either three elements to grab the first element and the third for the name or just uses the first element of the array for the name.

Allows (publicly allowed) query vars to be added, removed, or changed prior to executing the query. Needed to allow custom rewrite rules using your own arguments to work, or any other custom query variables you want to be publicly available.
Allows render_block() to be shortcircuited, by returning a non-null value.
Allows render_block() to be shortcircuited, by returning a non-null value.
Allows a plugin to override the WordPress.org Translation Installation API entirely.
Allows a plugin to register a new admin color scheme. For example:
Allows a plugin to replace the content that would otherwise be returned. The filter is ‘img_caption_shortcode’ and passes an empty string, the attr parameter and the content parameter values.
Allows a theme to de-register its support of a certain feature
Allows additional query args to be appended.
Allows applications to identify themselves when they’re doing a redirect.
Allows checking for comment flooding.
Allows current multisite naming conventions when checking for properties.
Allows current multisite naming conventions when checking for properties. Checks for extended site properties.
Allows current multisite naming conventions when getting properties.
Allows current multisite naming conventions when getting properties. Allows access to extended site properties.
Allows current multisite naming conventions while setting properties.
Allows for PHP file wrappers.
Allows for Windows network shares.
Allows for the addition and/or removal of potential enclosures to save to postmeta before checking the database for existing enclosures.
Allows hijacking the setting update logic and overriding the built-in behavior by returning true.
Allows modification of the attachment right before it is returned.
